channel.title: I need a little help please :P

item.title: I need a little help please :P
item.dc:creator: @fate fate
item.description:
@fate wrote:

hey thanks unlimited, wasn’t sure if I could only use 1 for them, never tried it. I have also one more problem. When I create an account and it saves the the .txt files, how do I get so it writes a new username and password under the current one in the .txt files? It just erases the ones in it and replaces it with the new one. Here is my code.

if (source == create) { String username = JOptionPane.showInputDialog(this, "Username: "); String password = JOptionPane.showInputDialog(this, "Password: "); try { BufferedWriter writeUsername = new BufferedWriter(new FileWriter("username.txt")); writeUsername.write(username); writeUsername.close(); BufferedWriter writePassword = new BufferedWriter(new FileWriter("password.txt")); writePassword.write(password); writePassword.close(); } catch (IOException ioe) { } return; }

I had writeUsername.newLine(); but that didn’t work so I just took it out.

Read full topic
item.source: I need a little help please :P

item.title: I need a little help please :P
item.dc:creator: @unlimitedorb unlimitedorb
item.description:
@unlimitedorb wrote:

What is the code segment for where the variables “username” and “password” are inputted? Also, I don’t understand why you are using multiple try-catch clauses? If an IOException is thrown then it can be caught with only one try-catch clause.

It’s also beneficial to use System.out.println() to print the variables being used in order to determine if they are correct in the first place e.g. before the line “if (userName.equals(username) && passWord.equals(password)) {” you could insert:

System.out.println("Flat file username: " + userName + "\nInput username: " + username + "\n\nFlat file password: " + passWord + "\nInput password: " + password);

Read full topic

item.title: I need a little help please :P
item.dc:creator: @cartridges cartridges
item.description:
@cartridges wrote:

Try outputting the values… A visual comparison should show you your fault… But judging by your lack of experience with AWT I’d say you didn’t copy username/password from the input fields… Unless, wait, is username/password a TextField? If so, you want to compare with the value, NOT the field.

item.title: I need a little help please :P
item.dc:creator: @fate fate
item.description:
@fate wrote:

Hi well I been trying to get this working for about 1 hour now. It is a login system, and you create an account and stuff, but I haven’t programmed in a long time so I am getting use to java again and I know this isnt anything good but its for me to get warmed back up. Well here is my code.

} public void actionPerformed(ActionEvent e) { Object source = e.getSource(); if (source == logOn) { try { BufferedReader readUsername = new BufferedReader(new FileReader("username.txt")); String userName = readUsername.readLine(); readUsername.close(); try { BufferedReader readPassword = new BufferedReader(new FileReader("password.txt")); String passWord = readPassword.readLine(); readPassword.close(); if (userName.equals(username) && passWord.equals(password)) { JOptionPane.showMessageDialog(this, "Log in Success!", "Success!", JOptionPane.INFORMATION_MESSAGE); } else { JOptionPane.showMessageDialog(this, "Invalid Username/Passowrd!", "Invalid!", JOptionPane.INFORMATION_MESSAGE); } } catch (IOException ioe) { } } catch (IOException ioe) { } return; }

My problem is everytime I try to logon I get invalid username and password no matter what I do. Even though in the username.txt and password.txt it is correct. Anyone care to help me fix this problem?

Thanks.

Fate

Read full topic
